title: Ownership in Orbit: The Global Treaty for Space Mining Rights
excerpt: With commercial lunar missions now a monthly occurrence, the United Nations has ratified the 'Artemis Fairness Accord,' the first legal framework for the extraction and ownership of extra-terrestrial resources.

content.text: The moon is no longer just a destination for exploration; it is the next frontier of global industry. This month, 120 nations officially signed the 'Space Resource Management Treaty' in Vienna, ending a decade of legal ambiguity regarding who owns the minerals found on celestial bodies. The treaty establishes the 'Common Heritage/Private Incentive' balance, allowing corporations to claim ownership of extracted materials while mandating that and the actual 'territory' remains the property of no state.

The primary focus of current lunar mining is 'Volatiles'â€”specifically water ice found in the permanently shadowed craters of the lunar south pole. This ice can be converted into liquid hydrogen and oxygen, creating 'Orbital Gas Stations' that will drastically reduce the cost of missions to Mars and beyond. The new treaty establishes 'Safety Zones' around these critical resource nodes to prevent the type of geopolitical 'land grabs' that have historically plagued terrestrial frontiers.

A breakthrough clause in the treaty is the 'Universal Space Dividend.' Any corporation extracting resources from the Moon or asteroids must pay a 10% 'Innovation Levy' on their net proceeds. This fund is then distributed to developing nations to help them build their own space-tracking and satellite infrastructure, ensuring that the 'Space Gold Rush' doesn't just benefit the wealthiest 1% of nations.
We are not just drafting a law for the Moon; we are drafting a constitution for our future as a multi-planetary species. The rules we set today will define our expansion for the next century.
content.author: Dr. Kenji Tanaka, UN Office for Outer Space Affairs

content.text: The treaty also includes strict 'De-orbiting and Debris Management' mandates. Commercial actors are now legally responsible for the entire lifecycle of their equipment, with heavy penalties for any company that leaves 'dead' satellites or launch stages in high-traffic orbits. As the first robotic mining drills begin to touch down on the lunar surface, the Vienna Treaty provides the essential legal scaffolding for a sustainable and equitable space economy.
